label: A_mP64_14_16e-002
title: $\beta$-monoclinic Sulfur Structure
comments:
We take the name of this structure from (Donohue, 1976).  This is the high temperature phase of sulfur, stable from 95$^\circ$C to the melting point at 115$^\circ$C, although it can be kept at room temperatures for some time. (Templeton, 1976) 
 This is a refinement of the original structure found by (Sands, 1965).  There are two types of sulfur atoms in this sample: \begin{itemize} \item atoms S-I through S-VIII form stable sulfur rings with all the sites fully occupied, just as in the ground state \href{current_web_home_dir/A_oF128_70_4h-001}{$\alpha$-S ($A16$)}. \item Atoms S-IX through S-XVI form a ring with one of two orientations, randomly chosen. \end{itemize} ~ \vspace{-.25in} 
 The S-IX through S-XVI sites are thus half occupied, so there are only 48 atoms and six sulfur rings in any unit cell.  Contrast this with \href{current_web_home_dir/A_mP64_14_16e-001}{$A_{k}$ selenium}, which has eight complete rings in the unit cell. 
 Both \href{current_web_home_dir/A_mP64_14_16e-001}{$A_{k}$ selenium} and $\beta$-monoclinic sulfur have the same AFLOW prototype label, A\_mP64\_14\_16e.  They are generated by the same symmetry operations with different sets of parameters ({\tt --params}) specified in their corresponding CIF files.
